content: Explain token expiration in authentication and session management.
explanation: Token expiration limits how long an authentication token is valid. This reduces risk if a token is leaked or stolen and forces users to re-authenticate after a set period.

title: Minimum Coins to Make Amount
content:
Given coins of different denominations and a total amount, find the minimum number of coins needed.

Example: coins = [1, 2, 5], amount = 11 → 3 (5 + 5 + 1)
explanation: Use dynamic programming: create array dp where dp[i] represents minimum coins for amount i. Initialize dp[0] = 0. For each coin, update dp[i + coin] = min(dp[i + coin], dp[i] + 1).

options.text: Use dynamic programming: dp[i] = min coins for amount i. For each coin, update dp[i + coin]. Time: O(amount * coins.length), Space: O(amount)
Use greedy: always pick largest coin. Time: O(amount), Space: O(1)
Try all combinations using recursion. Time: O(2ⁿ), Space: O(n)
Sort coins and use largest first. Time: O(n log n), Space: O(1)

title: Find Container With Most Water
content:
Given an array of heights, find two lines that together with x-axis form a container that holds the most water.

Example: [1, 8, 6, 2, 5, 4, 8, 3, 7] → 49
explanation: Use two pointers technique: start with pointers at both ends. Calculate area (min(height[left], height[right]) * (right - left)). Move the pointer with smaller height inward, as moving the larger one cannot increase area.

options.text: Use two pointers at start and end. Move pointer with smaller height. Calculate area and track max. Time: O(n), Space: O(1)
Try all pairs of lines. Time: O(n²), Space: O(1)
Find two tallest lines. Time: O(n), Space: O(1)
Sort heights and use top two. Time: O(n log n), Space: O(n)

title: Find Longest Palindromic Substring
content:
Given a string, find the longest palindromic substring.

Example: "babad" → "bab" or "aba"
explanation: Expand around center: for each possible center (considering both odd and even length palindromes), expand outward while characters match. Track the longest palindrome found. More space-efficient than DP.

options.text: Expand around center for each possible center (odd and even length). Track longest. Time: O(n²), Space: O(1)
Check all possible substrings. Time: O(n³), Space: O(1)
Use dynamic programming. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n²)
Reverse string and find longest common substring. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n²)

title: Find All Unique Triplets That Sum to Zero
content:
Given an array, find all unique triplets that sum to zero.

Example: [-1, 0, 1, 2, -1, -4] → [[-1, -1, 2], [-1, 0, 1]]
explanation: Sort the array first. For each element, use two pointers (left and right) to find pairs that sum to the negative of the current element. Skip duplicate values to avoid duplicate triplets.

options.text: Sort array. For each element, use two pointers to find pairs that sum to negative of current element. Skip duplicates. Time: O(n²), Space: O(1) excluding output
Use three nested loops. Time: O(n³), Space: O(1)
Use hash map for all pairs, then check for third element. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n²)
Find all combinations using recursion. Time: O(2ⁿ), Space: O(n)

title: Find Longest Increasing Subsequence
content:
Given an array, find the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence.

Example: [10, 9, 2, 5, 3, 7, 101, 18] → 4 ([2, 3, 7, 101])
explanation: Two approaches: 1) DP: for each element, check all previous elements and update LIS length. 2) Binary search: maintain array of smallest tail values, use binary search to find insertion point (more efficient O(n log n)).

options.text: Use dynamic programming: dp[i] = length of LIS ending at i. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n)
Use binary search with patience sorting. Maintain array of smallest tail of increasing subsequences. Time: O(n log n), Space: O(n)
Try all possible subsequences. Time: O(2ⁿ), Space: O(n)
Sort array and find longest consecutive sequence. Time: O(n log n), Space: O(1)

title: Group Strings by Anagram
content:
Given an array of strings, group anagrams together.

Example: ["eat", "tea", "tan", "ate", "nat", "bat"] → [["eat","tea","ate"], ["tan","nat"], ["bat"]]
explanation: Two approaches: 1) Sort each string and use sorted string as key in hash map. 2) Use character frequency count as key (more efficient). Group strings with same key together.

options.text: Use sorted string as key in hash map. Group strings with same sorted key. Time: O(n*k log k) where k is avg string length, Space: O(n*k)
Compare each string with all others. Time: O(n²*k), Space: O(n)
Use character frequency as key. Time: O(n*k), Space: O(n*k)
Sort entire array and group adjacent anagrams. Time: O(n*k log(n*k)), Space: O(n*k)

title: Product of Array Except Self
content:
Given an array, return an array where each element is the product of all other elements (without using division).

Example: [1, 2, 3, 4] → [24, 12, 8, 6]
explanation: Use two passes: first pass calculates left products (product of all elements to the left), second pass multiplies by right products (product of all elements to the right). This avoids division and handles zeros.

options.text: Two passes: left products, then right products. Multiply corresponding elements. Time: O(n), Space: O(1) excluding output
Calculate product of all elements, divide by each element. Time: O(n), Space: O(1)
For each element, calculate product of all others. Time: O(n²), Space: O(1)
Use nested loops to calculate products. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n)

title: Find Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
content:
Given a string, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

Example: "abcabcbb" → 3 ("abc")
explanation: Use sliding window technique with a hash map. Expand window by moving right pointer, track characters in current window. When duplicate found, move left pointer past the duplicate. Track maximum window size.

options.text: Use sliding window with hash map. Expand window, shrink when duplicate found. Time: O(n), Space: O(min(n, m)) where m is charset size
Check all possible substrings. Time: O(n³), Space: O(n)
Use Set and check each substring. Time: O(n²), Space: O(n)
Sort characters and find longest sequence. Time: O(n log n), Space: O(n)

title: Validate Sudoku Board
content:
Determine if a 9x9 Sudoku board is valid (no duplicates in rows, columns, or 3x3 boxes).

Example: Valid board returns true
explanation: Use hash sets to track seen numbers in each row, column, and 3x3 box. For each cell, check if the number exists in the corresponding row, column, and box sets. Since board is fixed 9x9, complexity is O(1).

options.text: Use three sets of hash maps: one for rows, one for columns, one for boxes. Check each cell against all three. Time: O(1) - fixed 81 cells, Space: O(1)
Check each row, column, and box separately. Time: O(1), Space: O(1)
Use nested loops to check all combinations. Time: O(n⁴), Space: O(1)
Sort each row, column, and box. Time: O(1), Space: O(1)

title: Find Word in 2D Grid
content:
Given a 2D board and a word, determine if the word exists in the board (can move horizontally or vertically).

Example: board with "ABCE", "SFCS", "ADEE" and word "ABCCED" → true
explanation: Use backtracking with DFS: for each cell matching first character, recursively search in all 4 directions. Mark cells as visited during recursion, unmark during backtracking. Return true if word found.

options.text: Use backtracking with DFS. For each cell, explore all directions, mark visited, backtrack. Time: O(m*n*4^L) where L is word length, Space: O(L)
Try all possible paths using BFS. Time: O(m*n*4^L), Space: O(m*n)
Check each cell independently. Time: O(m*n*L), Space: O(1)
Convert board to string and search. Time: O(m*n), Space: O(m*n)
